metadata.case_name: Pipraich Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Their Workmen

facts.text: Appellant is a limited company carrying on business in crushing sugarcane at Pipraich in Gorakhpur District from 1932.
In 1946, appellant decided to expand business, sold old machinery (160 tons/day capacity), purchased new one (650 tons capacity), installed in 1947, started working 1948-49.

Sugar industry crisis due to shortage of sugarcane; Government assumed control of production and supply; quota allotted to appellant's mill too small, leading to losses of Rs. 2,67,042-7-4 in 1948-49 and 1949-50.
On May 11, 1950, management wrote to Government to increase quota or permit sale of mills.
In October 1950, Government granted permission for sale of plant and machinery; sold to Madras party.
Appellant obtained lease from purchaser for current crushing season, to deliver possession at end.
Appellant negotiating to dismantle machinery and erect at Madras for lump consideration using own workmen.
Workmen, through union (respondent), hostile to sale as it would throw them out of employment; moved Government to cancel permission.
Union passed resolution on December 26, 1950, to go on strike from January 12, 1951, communicated to appellant.
On January 3, 1951, Managing Director offered 25% of profit on sale to Madras party, subject to immediate withdrawal of strike notice.
Union reply January 5, 1951: Fight with Government, not resolved; waiting for President Kashinath Pandey.
Management reply January 8, 1951: Ready to reconsider terms but insist on strike notice withdrawal.
January 9, 1951: Kashinath Pandey discussed with management.
January 10, 1951: General Manager wrote acceding to union points if strike notice withdrawn at once; compensation not less than a lac.
Union reply same day: Waiting for Kashinath Pandey; strike not coming off from 12th.
No strike occurred; crushing continued till end of January 1951.
Lease expired end of crushing season; purchaser arrived to take delivery and dismantle.
Workmen refused to cooperate in dismantling out of sentiment.
Notice February 28, 1951: Workers to cooperate or consider discharged from March 1, 1951; 15 days notice.
March 4, 1951: Kashinath Pandey threatened hunger strike if mills shifted.
Notice March 14, 1951: Workers discharged from March 1, 1951, subject to 15 days wages; collect on 15-16th.
After March 14 notice, Kashinath Pandey discussed; termination extended to March 21 pending Government decision; workmen to dismantle after.
Government letter March 21, 1951: Declined to interfere with sale.
Workmen declined to cooperate in dismantling from March 21; management discharged them per notices.
Purchaser contracted directly with workmen on April 1, 1951 for dismantling; appellant lost contract worth at least Rs. 2 lakhs profit.
Union notice April 19, 1951: Demand 25% labour-share of profits on sale.
Appellant repudiated June 19, 1951: Referred to non-cooperation causing loss.
U.P. Government notification November 16, 1951 under s.3 U.P. Industrial Disputes Act: Referred dispute to Industrial Tribunal.
Industrial Tribunal award February 28, 1952: Closure bona fide; workmen conduct unfair but promise in Jan letters binding; Rs.45,000 payable.
Labour Appellate Tribunal confirmed July 21, 1953.

legal_issues.text: Whether the notification dated November 16, 1951 referring the dispute to Industrial Tribunal under s.3 U.P. Industrial Disputes Act is ultra vires as industry closed and no employer-employee relationship.
Whether there was a concluded and binding agreement by appellant to pay 25% of profits on sale transaction to workmen.
Whether termination of services on closure of business constitutes retrenchment entitling workmen to compensation.

petitioner_arguments.text: Notification ultra vires as no industrial dispute post-closure; requires existing industry and employer-employee relationship.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 3 U.P. Industrial Disputes Act 1947; s.2(k) Industrial Disputes Act 1947; Indian Metal and Metallurgical Corporation v. Industrial Tribunal, Madras; K. N. Padmanabha Ayyar v. State of Madras

petitioner_arguments.text: No concluded agreement; offers conditional on strike withdrawal, not accepted; strike did not occur but no acceptance.
Closure bona fide due to losses; paid all dues; no retrenchment compensation as no amendment in 1951.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Industrial Disputes Act 1947 (pre-1953 amendment); J. K. Hosiery Factory v. Labour Appellate Tribunal

respondent_arguments.text: Promise in January 3 and 10 letters binding; no strike amounted to acceptance by conduct; consideration by continued service.
Retrenchment includes discharge on closure; compensation awardable even pre-1953.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.2(oo) and s.25F Industrial Disputes Act 1947; Employees of India Reconstruction Corporation v. India Reconstruction Corporation; Benett Coleman & Co. v. Their Employees

court_reasoning.text: Industrial dispute exists if arose in existing industry between employer-employee; reference valid if right accrued before closure, even if notified later.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Power under s.3 determined by date dispute/right arose, not reference date.

court_reasoning.text: No concluded agreement: Offers lapsed unaccepted; conditional on strike withdrawal; no strike but explicit pending decision; workmen continued hostility and non-cooperation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Correspondence shows no acceptance; conduct not acceptance as required.

court_reasoning.text: Retrenchment does not include discharge on closure of business; pre-1953 law applies, no retrospective effect; tribunals' views erroneous.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Retrenchment means discharge of surplus in continuing business.

court_reasoning.text: Closure bona fide; workmen conduct disentitles compensation.

holdings.text: Reference under s.3 valid if industrial dispute arose in existing industry, notwithstanding subsequent closure.
No concluded binding agreement to pay 25% profits.
Termination on bona fide closure not retrenchment; no compensation payable under pre-1953 law.

precedents_cited.case_name: Indian Metal and Metallurgical Corporation v. Industrial Tribunal, Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Industrial dispute presupposes continued existence of industry.

precedents_cited.case_name: K. N. Padmanabha Ayyar v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: No industrial dispute re closed business.

precedents_cited.case_name: Burn & Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Labour legislation for existing industry; 1953 amendment not retrospective.

precedents_cited.case_name: J. K. Hosiery Factory v. Labour Appellate Tribunal
Employees of India Reconstruction Corporation Ltd. v. India Reconstruction Corporation Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Obiter on closure as retrenchment; not applicable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Benett Coleman & Co. Ltd. v. Their Employees
precedents_cited.relevance: Erroneous view that closure discharge is retrenchment.

statutes_cited.name: U. P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Empowers reference of industrial disputes; definition incorporates Industrial Disputes Act s.2(k).

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines industrial dispute and retrenchment; s.25F for compensation on retrenchment.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes (Amendment) Act, 1953
statutes_cited.relevance: Inserted s.2(oo) and s.25F; no retrospective operation.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; awards of Industrial Tribunal and Labour Appellate Tribunal set aside; no compensation payable to workmen as no binding agreement and no retrenchment on closure.
outcome.relief_granted: None to respondent; appellant's appeal upheld.

key_quotes.text: "the power of the State to make a reference under section 3 will depend, not only on the dispute having arisen in an existing industry but further, on the continued existence of that industry on the date of the notification."
key_quotes.speaker: petitioner

key_quotes.text: "We do not see how on this correspondence it could be held that there was a concluded agreement between the parties."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on no binding promise.

key_quotes.text: "retrenchment connotes in its ordinary acceptation that the business itself is being continued but that a portion of the staff or the labour force is discharged as surplusage."
key_quotes.speaker: court
